social_posts.post_text:
The most beloved words to Allah, the Almighty, are simple yet powerful. They hold within them the essence of worship, gratitude, and devotion. Subhan Allah, wal hamdulillah, wala ilaha illallah, wallahu Akbar.

Each of these words carries its own unique significance, yet when combined, they paint a vivid picture of our unwavering faith in the Almighty. Subhan Allah, glorifying Allah's perfection, is a declaration of our belief in His supremacy. Wal hamdulillah, the recognition of Allah's mercy and grace, is a token of our gratitude for His endless blessings.
Wala ilaha illallah, the assertion of our belief in Allah's oneness, is a declaration of our devotion to Him. And finally, wallahu Akbar, acknowledging Allah's greatness, is a testament to His power and might.

These words are not merely empty phrases, but a reflection of our relationship with the Creator. When we recite them with intention and devotion, they have the power to uplift our spirits and bring us closer to our Lord.

Let us make an effort to incorporate these beloved words into our daily lives and earn the rewards of paradise. May Allah grant us the wisdom to understand their true significance and make us among those who are beloved to Him.

Save this🍒 Secret to Unlock the 8 Gates of Jannah !

'Uqba b. 'Amir reported: 
We were entrusted with the task of tending the camels. On my turn when I came back in the evening after grazing them in the pastures, I found Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) stand and address the people. I heard these words of his: If any Muslim performs ablution well, then stands and prays two rak'ahs setting about them with his heart as well as his face, Paradise would be guaranteed to him. I said: What a fine thing is this! And a narrator who was before me said: The first was better than even this. When I cast a glance, I saw that it was 'Umar who said: I see that you have just come and observed: If anyone amongst you performs the ablution, and then completes the ablution well and then says: I testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the servant of Allah and His Messenger, the eight gates of Paradise would be opened for him and he may enter by whichever of them he wishes. 
This Hadith is Sahih 

Sahih Muslim, 234a
In-Book Reference: Book 2, Hadith 20
USC-MSA web (English) reference: Book 2, Hadith 451 (deprecated numbering scheme) 

This next Hadith is Found in Sunan Abi Dawud, 169

The words of this supplication flow like a gentle stream, carrying the heartfelt desires of the faithful to the heavens above. It is not just a beautiful prayer, but the most comprehensive of all, touching upon every aspect of life - both in this world and the next.

In this world, the supplication seeks all that brings joy and happiness to the heart - a loving spouse, a bountiful supply of halal sustenance, a child who brings light to one's life, knowledge that opens doors to success, a comfortable home, a fulfilling profession, ease and comfort, righteous deeds, and peace. It also asks for the simple pleasures of life, like a reliable mode of transportation and praise that uplifts the soul.

In the hereafter, the supplication reaches for the highest of ideals - protection from the trials of the grave, closeness to the Most Merciful, an easy reckoning, entrance into Paradise, the pleasure of Allah, eternal bliss, safe passage over the bridge on the Day of Judgment, a book held in the right hand, and a drink from the blessed waters of Kausar.

This supplication, with its comprehensive scope and its pure intent, is a shining gem among prayers, a testament to the power of faith and devotion.

#quran #dua #islamicreminder #loveislam #islamicreminders

Reward Of the whole Quran! Surah al Ikhlas stands tall as an emblem of monotheism in the Quran. This surah bears immense significance and holds extraordinary virtue in the religion. According to a hadith, the mere act of reading Surat al-Ikhlas once is equivalent to reading 1/3 of the entire Quran. And if one reads Surah al-Ikhlas three times, it is as if they have read the entire Quran. The brevity and density of this surah make its virtues all the more impressive. Therefore, reading this surah with sincerity can bring forth many advantages and benefits.

#Quran #islamicreminders #texas #michigan #london

Sleep is a mysterious and temporary state that can feel like a small death. During this time, our bodies are occupied with various processes beyond our conscious awareness. But, through Allah's mercy, we are granted a return to life upon waking, while some others are not as fortunate. This realisation should inspire us to express gratitude for this blessing every day.

To ensure we are able to rise each morning, whether it's from a full night's slumber before Fajr or a brief nap, we should make a dua for waking up. In the comments section below, you'll find Arabic, English, and transliterated versions of this powerful prayer. Let us remember to give thanks for the gift of life each time we awaken from sleep.

Rasul (sm) spoke these Dua three times and it brought more blessings and rewards than the many hours of worship that our dear mother Juwayreyyah (may Allah be pleased with her) had performed. Allahu akbar!

سبحان اللهِ وبحمدِه ، عددَ خلقِه ورضَا نفسِه وزِنَةِ عرشِه ومِدادَ كلماتِه
"Subhana-llahi wa behamdih, (1) ‘adada khalqihi, (2) wa reDa nafsihi, (3) wa zinata 'arshihi, (4) wa me dada kalemaatih.

To understand just how powerful the supplication is, let's take a closer look at each part of it. The dua starts with a phrase used by the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ):

"Subhana Allah", means "All glory be to Allah." But it actually has a deeper meaning. When we say "Subhana Allah," we are acknowledging that Allah is completely perfect and flawless. We affirm that Allah is free from any imperfections or shortcomings, and we reject any lies or falsehoods that may be spread about Allah by those who don't understand Him. 

"wa behamdih." means, “O Allah you are deserving of all praise”. By saying "wa behamdih," we declare that Allah alone is worthy of all praise and recognition. 

# 1. "adada khalqih," means, “By the amount and number of His creation”. It's hard to imagine just how many things Allah has created! Think about it - every human being, every jinn, every angel, every animal, every living and non-living thing, every grain of sand in the desert, every drop of water in the ocean, every star and plant, and so much more, Allahu akbar!

# 2. "Wa ReDa nafsih," means, “Until He is pleased!”. When we say this phrase, we are expressing our desire to please Allah in all that we do.

# 3. "Wa zenata 'arshih”, means “As heavy as His throne!”. When we say this phrase, we reflect on the vastness and magnificence of Allah's throne. 

# 4. "Wa medaada kalemaatih", means “And by the amount of ink and pens that are required to write down His words:” . When we say this phrase, we acknowledge the infinite nature of Allah's words. The amount of ink and pens required to write down His words is beyond measure, as they are countless and immeasurable. 

It is important to remember to recite this supplication three times every morning and to encourage others to do the same.

I can’t wait to meet our prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) in Jannah (paradise). Ameen ya Rabbi.  He was thinking about us when he was alive. What a blessing🥺

Source: Sahih Muslim 249a

Jannah will make Dua for you if you do this!

Anas bin Malik narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
"Whoever asks Allah (s.w.t) Paradise three times, Paradise says: 'O Allah, admit him into Paradise', and whoever seeks refuge from the Fire three times, the Fire says: ‘O Allah, save him from the Fire.’"
At-Tirmidhi Hadith 2572

And Don’t forget to share this video with your loved ones iA.

Dying in Medina: Promise of Prophet Muhammad (saw)

Prophet Muhammad (sm) encouraging believers to die in Medina, if possible. This statement emphasizes the spiritual significance of Medina, a city unique in its divine blessing. While Makkah holds the revered Kaaba, Medina is the only location the Prophet prayed for regarding the virtue of passing away there. Those who die in Medina receive the Prophet's intercession on the Day of Judgment, which, according to scholars, assures a place in Paradise.

3 Amazing Facts About Islam! ✨😍

🌟 Fact #1: In Islam, daughters are not considered a burden but a blessing. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) conveyed, "Anyone who has three daughters and provides for them, clothes them, and shows mercy to them will definitely enter Jannah (Paradise)." Even with two daughters, the promise stands. (Hadith Source: Al-Adab Al-Mufrad 78 [https://sunnah.com/adab:78])

🌟 Fact #2: Islam allows a direct connection with Allah. The Quran affirms, "When My servants ask you about Me, I am truly near. I respond to one’s prayer when they call upon Me." No intermediaries are required; believers have a personal connection with the Almighty.

🌟 Fact #3: Islam promotes unity and rejects racism or casteism. Allah instructs in the Quran, "And hold firmly to the rope of Allah all together and do not become divided." Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) emphasized the unity of Muslims as a single body, evident in practices like standing shoulder to shoulder in prayer. Share this video to spread the joy and understanding of Islam, bridging gaps and fostering unity. 🌍✨ If you have more examples of Islamic unity, share them in the comments below! 👇⬇️

We all live different lives, and each life comes with its own set of challenges. In our face-to-face experiences, we encounter many ups and downs. We need to deal with hits and setbacks in our life journey. Those who can stay positive and act normal have some special qualities. But, it's okay if we don't have those qualities – life is normal and real even without them.

If someone doesn't talk with a smile, doesn't ask smart questions when we meet, or doesn't reply to our messages, maybe they are going through a tough time. Let's not misunderstand them.

Inside, they might be facing a struggle that we can't see. They might be feeling really lonely. The world might seem confusing and overwhelming to them. Maybe, they just need a bit of time for themselves.

With this understanding, let's be kind to each other. Let's try to understand their feelings, like how Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) understood Bishor (RA) heart. If possible, we can ask, 'Can I help you?' or 'If you ever feel like talking about your problems, feel free to call me anytime. I'm here for you.'

[Translated from Arif Azad]
